content: The Act is titled the "Brownfield Redevelopment and Economic Development Innovative Financing Act of 2014." It establishes a program for innovative financing for brownfield redevelopment and economic development. The Act establishes the Brownfield Redevelopment and Economic Development Innovative Financing program to guarantee loans for brownfield redevelopment and urban renewal projects. Eligibility requirements include applications from local governments and redevelopment agencies. The Program guarantees loans for brownfield redevelopment and urban renewal projects. Eligibility requires submission of a master plan meeting specific requirements. To be eligible for a loan guarantee under the Program, a government, agency, or BRAC redevelopment project must submit a master plan meeting requirements, along with certification of environmental remediation need for the brownfield to be redeveloped. To be eligible for a loan guarantee under the Program, a government, agency, or BRAC redevelopment project must submit a master plan meeting requirements, along with certification of environmental remediation need for the brownfield to be redeveloped. The loan must be used for costs of carrying out a project to redevelop brownfields. Additional information may be required by the Secretary. A loan guaranteed under the Program must be used for brownfield redevelopment projects, including site acquisition, remediation, and facility relocation. The Secretary may require additional information. The project aims to redevelop brownfields for urban renewal, involving site acquisition, remediation, facility relocation, and site preparation. The Program prohibits loan guarantees for redevelopment projects if the applying agency caused contamination on the brownfield site. The Program prohibits loan guarantees for redevelopment projects if the applying agency caused contamination on the brownfield site. Additionally, a local government, redevelopment agency, or BRAC project cannot have more than one outstanding loan guaranteed under the Program, with a minimum loan amount of $25,000,000. The Program prohibits more than one outstanding loan guaranteed for redevelopment projects, with a minimum loan amount of $25,000,000 and a maximum of $150,000,000 based on project cost. The interest rate is negotiated between the lender and the borrower. The loan for redevelopment projects can be up to $150,000,000 with an interest rate negotiated between the lender and borrower. The loan term is between 20 to 30 years for repayment. The loan term for redevelopment projects is between 20 to 30 years, with no repayment of principal or interest required within the first 10 years after receiving the loan. Repayment is subject to negotiation between the lender and borrower. The loan term for brownfield redevelopment projects is between 20 to 30 years. Repayment of principal or interest is not required within the first 10 years after receiving the loan, and repayment must begin within 15 years of receiving the loan. A master plan must describe the proposed project for the loan guarantee. The loan term for brownfield redevelopment projects is 20 to 30 years, with repayment starting within 15 years of receiving the loan. A master plan must describe the project funded by the loan guarantee. The loan guarantee for brownfield redevelopment projects requires a description of the project, a budget, and a schedule of activities. It must demonstrate major redevelopment impact on the community, including non-Federal funds commitment and long-term job creation. The loan guarantee for brownfield redevelopment projects requires information on non-Federal funds commitment, long-term job creation, environmental remediation, economic impact on the community, and affordable housing creation. The loan guarantee for brownfield redevelopment projects requires information on environmental remediation, economic impact on the community, affordable housing creation, reduction of vehicle congestion and emissions, integration of green technology, and improvement in air quality. The loan guarantee for brownfield redevelopment projects requires evidence of commitments from non-Federal entities, integration of green technology, improvement in air quality, and incorporation of complete streets planning and transit-oriented development. The Secretary will establish selection criteria for local governments, redevelopment agencies, and BRAC projects to receive loan guarantees under the Program. The criteria will include evidence of non-Federal investment commitments, incorporation of complete streets planning and transit-oriented development, and an approved remediation action plan by the Environmental Protection Agency. The Secretary will establish selection criteria for local governments, redevelopment agencies, and BRAC projects to receive loan guarantees under the Program. Criteria will consider information required for approval, and existing BRAC projects with Federal assistance will receive favorable consideration. The Secretary will establish selection criteria for local governments, redevelopment agencies, and BRAC projects to receive loan guarantees under the Program, taking into consideration required information and giving favorable consideration to existing BRAC projects with Federal assistance. The full faith and credit of the United States is pledged to guarantee payments, with guarantees made by the Secretary being conclusive evidence of eligibility for such guarantees. The full faith and credit of the United States is pledged to guarantee payments under the Program. Any guarantee made by the Secretary is conclusive evidence of eligibility for the obligations. The Federal Government is protected against liability for environmental remediation. The Government is protected against liability for environmental remediation. The Secretary processes and approves loan guarantee requests using a specific approval process. The Secretary processes and approves loan guarantee requests under this section using a process similar to that used for loan guarantees under the Housing and Community Development Act of 1974. Applicants must demonstrate a viable repayment schedule and provide collateral to be eligible for a loan guarantee. The approval process for loan guarantees under section 108 of the Housing and Community Development Act of 1974 requires applicants to demonstrate a viable repayment schedule and provide sufficient collateral. This collateral may include a pledge of grants under title I of the Act. The Secretary may require sufficient collateral for loan guarantees under section 108 of the Housing and Community Development Act of 1974, which can be in forms other than grants. Congressional oversight is necessary before final approval of any loan guarantee. Congressional oversight is necessary before final approval of any loan guarantee. Definitions for a BRAC redevelopment project are also provided. Definitions for a BRAC redevelopment project include a project to redevelop a site designated as a Base Realignment and Closure Site by the Secretary of Defense. The term "brownfield" is defined as per the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980. The term "local redevelopment agency" refers to any State government entity focused on improving blighted areas. The term "remediation action plan" in the context of a brownfield redevelopment project describes the site remediation process and technology to be used. The "remediation action plan" for a brownfield redevelopment project outlines the site remediation process, technology to be used, and timeline for remediation actions. The Program refers to the Brownfield Redevelopment and Economic Development Innovative Financing program established under the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development will issue regulations for the Brownfield Redevelopment and Economic Development Innovative Financing program within 6 months of enactment. $100,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2015.
